document.docTitle: Some Nematodes From The Moor House National Nature Reserve, Westmorland

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Some Nematodes From The Moor House National Nature Reserve, Westmorland

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Zoology, Durham Colleges in the University of Durham, England

paragraph.docTitle: SOME NEMATODES FROM THE MOOR HOUSE NATIONAL NATURE RESERVE, WESTMORLAND

subSection.paragraph: BY
Department of Zoology, Durham Colleges in the University of Durham, England *

Information is given on nematodes collected over a period of two years from a British montane moorland area with predominantly acid peat soils. Thirty-eight genera and twenty-eight species were indentified, but although these vary in their distribution on the different habitats studied, no strictly moorland nematode fauna was found.

Apart from the work of Bastian (1865) and T. Goodey (1951) the nematode fauna of British soils, although abundant, has been little studied. Robertson (1929) published a list of nematodes from Scottish arable soils, but there is no reference to nematodes of moorland soils known to the writer. Between 1958 and 1960 nematodes were collected from an area of north Pennine moorland between 1,800 and 2,050 ft (550 and 630 m) in the Nature Conservancy's Moor House National Nature Reserve (Nat. Grid Ref. 35/758329). Conway (1955) has described the reserve which lies largely on the dip slope, descending to the upper Tees valley, in an area of severe montane climate ( Manley, 1936 , 1943 ).

Vegetation communities depend on the type and degree of waterlogging of the soil. Blanket bog, with
Calluna vulgaris
,
Erica spp.
,
Eriophorum spp.
and
Sphagnum spp.
, predominates on the peat soils. On the moor edge, where the peat is disturbed or re-distributed, and on the drift, sandstone and limestone outcrops, other plants (e.g.
Nardus strict
,
Juncus spp.
Deschampsia flexuosa
,
Festuca spp.
and
Agrostis tenuis
) take their place. In places the peat is extensively broken by haggs and eroded or bare of vegetation, often with the original Calluna-dominated vegetation left as a few 'residual' hummocks.

footnote.paragraph: * Present Address: Department of Zoology,Makerere College,Kampala,Uganda.

subSection.paragraph:
Five study sites were selected on the major vegetation habitats and these, together with the soil characteristics, are shown in Table I . In addition, collecting was carried out in Sphagnum-filled pools, alluvial soils, sheep dung and on the residual
Calluna
hummocks on the eroded peat.

paragraph.tableNote: I. H.— Index of Humidity, i. e. water content/soil dry weight. Columns 3 and 4 are attempts to fit the sites into the scheme of Pearsall (1950 , Fig. 16, p. 77).

subSection.paragraph: Table II gives the list of genera found details about which will be found in Banage (1960) . Information about their feeding habits and distribution will be published later.

tr.td: Very rarely in soil, largely in sheep dung.
Found both in soil and sheep dung.
The most abundant genus especially on peat soils.
Only one species, see Table III.

Occasionally on the Limestone and
Calluna
sites.

subSection.paragraph: DISTRIBUTION OF SPECIES

Table III summarises the distribution of species indentified. The list includes only two species of
Plectus
and none of Dorylaimtts but, except for these common but taxonomically difficult groups, the species given are among the commonest present. They fall into four groups.

(a) Those which are restricted to peat habitats, e . g .
Aphelenchoides saprophilus
,
Plectus tenuis
and probably
P . parietinus.

(b) Those restricted to mineral soils of the grassland sites. They include plant feeding types like
Helicotylenchus erythrinae
,
Rotylenchus robustus
and
Pratylenchus
pratensis , which are often reported from well drained meadows elsewhere. Also in these habitats are found
Tripyla spp.
,
Enchodelus macrodorus
,
Prionchulus muscorum
and some other Mononchidae . Species of
Aporcelaimus
,
Tylencholaimellus
and
Actinolaimus
were also found only on these soils.

(c) Widespread species, e . g .
Tylenchus ( Aglenchus ) agricola
,
Teratocephalus terrestris
and
Prismatolaimus dolichurus
. These occurred on peat and mineral soils indiscriminately.

(d) One or two species which were found on mineral soils but which occurred also on the better drained peat, e.g.
Tylenchorhynchus sp.
and
Criconema murrayi
.

In Danish soils ( Overgaard Nielsen, 1949 , Table 17), of the species similar or related to those found at Moor House ,
Wilsonema auriculatum
was encountered only on peat,
Tripyla setifera
and
Rotylenchus robustus
only on sandy soils. As at Moor House,
Teratocephalus terrestris
and
Prismatolaimus dolichurus
occurred both on sandy and peat soils.
Tylenchus filiformis
and
Aphelenchoides parietinus
were widespread in Danish soils. However, Andrassy (1954) has shown that
T . filiformis de Man, 1876
and 1880, may be the same as
T . ( Aglenchus ) agricola
. Also, Franklin (1957) suggests that some of the records of A.
parietinus
in the earlier literature may refer to
A . saprophilus
which is widespread in decaying organic matter. It is, therefore, likely that the distribution of
T . ( Aglenchus ) agricola
and
A . saprophilus
in Danish and Moor House soils are similar.

paragraph.emphasis: The distribution of species by sites

subSection.paragraph: The unexpected abundance and variety of the fauna of the upland moorland areas, with their hard climate, invite comparison with other areas in Britain and Europe. Svendsen (1957) found that of the seventeen common British Lumbricids fifteen occurred at Moor House . Coulson (1959) who investigated the Tipulid fly fauna of the same area, found that the ratio of the strictly moorland species to that of all the species occurring at Moor House and that of British species was about 5: 22: 100. Significantly, the Tipulid fauna was shown to have affinity with that of Scandinavia.

The information on the nematodes is scanty, but at Moor House, of the twenty species determined (Table III), only seven were sufficiently distinct from any of the known species to be regarded as undescribed. The other twenty-one are widely distributed, some of them e.g.
Panagrolaimus rigidus
,
Criconema murrayi
,
Prionchulus muscorum
and
Enchodelus macrodorus
being reputedly cosmopolitan. Some of these, however, may be aggregates of closely related forms and further study may help to separate them.

This work was done while the author held a Toro Native Government (Uganda) Overseas Scholarship. Thanks are due to Prof. J. B. Cragg for direction and encouragement, to Dr. J. B. Goodey for taxonomic help and to both for advice about the preparation of the manuscript. Thanks are also due to the Nature Conservancy for access to their Nature Reserve.

ZUSAMMENFASSUNG Einige Nematoden aus dem Moor House Nationalpark , Westmorland Die Nematoden wurden 2 Jahre lang von einer Fläche mit saurem Torfboden gesammelt. 38 Gattungen und 28 Arten wurden identifiziert. Die Arten können eingeteilt werden in solche, die sich auf Torfböden beschränken, solche, die sich auf Mineralböden beschränken, solche, die auf Mineralböden und besser drainierten Torfböden vorkommen und schliesslich solche, die weitverbreitet sind. Ausser 7 nicht beschriebenen Arten ist der Rest geographisch weit verbreitet. Eine typische Moorland-Nematodenfauna gibt es nicht.
